title: Daniel J. Boorstein's "The Discoverers" | Review of First Half
description: I gave this speech for class. It is a critical book review of Daniel J. Boorstein's History book "The Discoverers." This speech was originally given on December 10th, 2021.

transcript_parts.text: in his book the discoverers daniel j
bornstein said in the preface this is a
story without end all the world is still
in america the most promising words ever
written on the maps of human knowledge
are terra incognita unknown
territory dion j borenstein's book the
discoverers is a book about world
history both ancient and modern his
major thesis is as the title conveys the
discovery or man's discovering of
certain fundamental things that we know
about today
so that could basically be his thesis to
set out to discover what we know i want
to focus on some of the things that i
feel like were negatives in the book
some of the things that were positive
and how these positives and negatives
kind of interplay with one another the
first thing that i want to bring out
that was negative because i'll focus on
the negatives first is he seems to have
a positive
positivistic view of discovery now what
i mean by that is bornstein seems to
think that if only people weren't
imprisoned by religion and politics and
their government then they would just
naturally go and discover
great things he brings up china if only
china didn't have an government which
encroached on their freedoms then they
would have discovered different things
about time and the earth before the
europeans did however i find this point
insufficient in that
how come
all the people who
i don't think that is the case that if
you just have
lack of say negative influence that
you're going to go out and discover
something you actually have to have a
positive motivation in order to
i guess influence you into wanting to
discover something so that's the first
point the second point is that he
doesn't understand medieval christianity
bornstein seems to think that
just because you're religious means that
you're basically brainwashed one of the
most interesting points that he brings
up historically is a christian
cosmographer cosmos of alexandria now he
brings up cosmos idea that the earth was
flat that
the
earth could be plotted in
i guess rather
less insufficient empirical way and that
he was basically just making up what he
thought the earth ought to be however if
you look deeper into the ideas of cosmos
and cosmos influence on christian
geography during the medieval time
period you find that this isn't exactly
the case david c lindbergh who has
devoted his career to the study of
medieval history and in his book the
medieval christians 680 to 1400 a.d he
notes that the only significance that
cosmos has for us today
is that he has been used to unfairly
accuse the christians of believing in a
flat earth
at the same time that bornstein is
criticizing christianity he at the same
time praises other
regions and religions such as the
chinese in the same chapter chapter 13
that bornstein says well cosmos made
everyone believe that the earth was flat
in europe he says that the chinese were
sophisticated and their mathematical
calculations were far ahead of ptolemy
and the other european influences
however a problem with this is that a
couple paragraphs later he knows the
chinese believed that the earth was flat
and not only that they believed that the
earth was flat and that it was
rectangular and not only that they also
believed that they could map the world
onto a grid and they would arbitrarily
plop cities into uh
on different places on their grid so
that it looked
nice
now christians aren't or medieval
christianity isn't exactly exempt from
this accusation entirely the medieval
christians definitely thought of the
world as
deeply imbued with
symbolic meaning the earth was basically
had four parts to it
almost looked like a cross and jerusalem
was in the middle but the problem or i
guess the difference between i guess
chinese cosmography and christian
cosmography is that there was actually
meaning
and reason behind
why christians thought this way now
perhaps they were wrong empirically but
we have to think beyond the empirical
things into symmetry and symbolic
truths and metaphorical truths if you
will and get beyond our modern
enlightenment framework
the next thing that i want to bring up
is this phrase that i've um i guess
partly thought up and partly stolen from
shakespeare to ptolemy or not to ptolemy
this is the question for bornstein and
the discoverers in some places such as
on and i have some pages and i won't
read off all the page numbers but page
220 21 97 219 among other places
bornstein has a very
warm very deep-throated like
support for ptolemy's geography calling

only people would have followed ptolemy
they would have known what the world was
like while on the nautitullamy side on
pages such as 111 263 245 242 225 among
other places
he says that well they were imprisoned
by ptolemy they couldn't think
because they were just following what
ptolemy had said now this is a this is
obviously a paradox in that in some
places he is very much praising told me
everyone should follow ptolemy in other
places you're imprisoned by total me so
we have this question to tell me or not
to tolerate me and bernstein doesn't
exactly answer that
the last thing that i want to bring up
as far as the negatives go is that of
islam now bornstein has a kind of
strange relationship to islam to put it
succinctly and some places such as on

religious freedom and the renaissance
and how in places like the netherlands
religious freedom was really high and
um in places like france and italy it
was really low he says that some people
would even go to arab countries to where

now this is empirically i guess and
evidentially untrue if you read the

than christianity so we're left with
this question that we can ask warnstein
so was islam tolerant or not tolerant
it's not only that he is arguing for

he's kind of contradicting himself as in

flat contradictions it doesn't mean that
his writing isn't interesting it just
means that they're kind of these
tensions in the text which aren't really
fleshed out all the way
on the side of the positives and the
things that i really liked is that
reading the discoveries is a very
interesting experience he really brings
out
man's need to discover things he's very
good at documenting actual events that

closer
let's say more personal reasons why

and he's very good at actually i would

on time
he's very good at documenting what

why they thought it according to their
religion and other things but his

they weren't say the chinese weren't
able to discover time before the

that's when i feel like his case starts
to fall apart he's very good historian
let's say but he's not a very good
analyzer of history he's i would say
he's good at the what but doesn't really
understand the why
so
um to conclude
my
critical book review of daniel j
bornstein's the discovers i want to
again point out this
interesting relationship that i think is
in the text bornstein very well tells
the story of history he tells the story
of man discovering things
but he can't really see beneath the
surface he can't really see let's say
the spiritual aspects of why man is
discovering things i find this
fascinating
for one particular reason and this
reason is that as
christians as we all are we actually
ought to discover things we actually
ought to discover things for reason not
just because well we should to improve
our lives but actually to take every
thought captive
to the glory of christ and that is
really our motivating force and that has
been the motivating force of almost all
the things that we see around us today
all these inventions all these
discoveries and that is the reason to or
that is the answer to bornstein's
question why the west and not the east
well it's the west and not the east
because we have christ because we have a
reason to discover and so i just want to
i guess encourage us all to be
discoverers in whatever way that
we can be and that we would take those
thoughts captive for christ and his
kingdom thank you
